title: Bolivian protesters clash with police over President Morales' 'fraudulent' election victory
text:
Bolivia was hit by more mass demonstrations Monday when hundreds of protesters clashed with rival demonstrators and security forces in the capital of La Paz over claims President Evo Morales committed of election fraud.

Images of a bloodied faces hinted at a day of violence as the president's supporters fought with opposition groups, while riot police fired tear gas to disperse the crowds.

The South American country has been convulsed by protests since October 20, when its Supreme Electoral Tribunal (TSE) abruptly suspended the publication of results from an electronic count.

The opposition is protesting election fraud that they claim awarded President Morales a fourth term in office.

Police responded with tear gas in an attempt to dispel a throng of anti-government supporters in La Pax, Bolivia, on Monday

A man stands near the police, who barricade themselves, from rioting protesters in the Bolivian capital city of La Paz on Monday

With 84% of votes counted, polling showed Morales was likely headed to a run-off with chief rival and ex-president Carlos Mesa. But when reporting of the count resumed after a nearly 24-hour pause, Morales had pulled off a razor-thin victory.

The final, legally-binding vote tally gave him 47.08 percent of votes to Mesa's 35.51 percent, less than a percentage point over the 10-point lead needed to avoid a run-off and giving him another five-year term.

'Morales made a mistake,' Mesa told protesters on Sunday, adding that discontent with the leftist president has been fermenting since voters rejected his attempt to lift term limits in 2016.

Images of a bloodied man's face offered a glimpse of Monday's protest that pitted President Evo Morales' supports and his detractors, who charge fraud was committed in order to help him avoid a run-off in the October 20 elections

A man hurls a stone during mass demonstrations in La Paz, Bolivia, on Monday

A court ruling later gave Morales, who has been in office nearly 14 years and is Latin America's longest-serving head of state, the green light to run once again.

The streets of La Paz, which has a million residents, were half-empty on Monday morning, with many shops and schools shuttered. The opposition-controlled mayor's office was also closed.

Road blockades mounted by residents using cars, wood planks, rope and even dumpsters were visible in both the middle-class south and working-class north of the city, according to Reuters witnesses.

'We are demanding that our vote be respected,' said Marta Colque, 32, who works at a daycare center.

Morales wants to 'stay forever', Colque said, as she stood at a blockade in the city center.

Mesa is 'a bad loser, a man who incites violence' despite his 'moral defeat' in the elections, Vice President Alvaro Garcia told journalists on Monday.

A demonstrators shows off a drawing of Bolivian President Evo Morales, who had pulled off a razor-thin victory in the South American country's election October 20

People cross a blocked street next to a cross reading 'Equality' during a strike for the results of the October 20 Bolivian presidential elections

The government is calling for people to go about their daily activities as normal, Garcia added, even as miners who back Morales gathered to counter-protest in La Paz.

People in Santa Cruz, Bolivia's industrial center, have been on strike since Wednesday of last week.

The Bolivian government said on Sunday it planned to agree a deal with the Organization of American States within days to audit the election.

Morales, 60, has said he will go to a second round if irregularities are found, but also that rural supporters could put cities under siege if they keep protesting his re-election. The TSE and Morales deny any election fraud.

Evo Morales (pictured) pulled off a razor-thin victory and according to a vote count, he received 47.08% of the votes to presidential candidate and former president Carlos Mesa's 35.51%, less than a percentage point over the 10-point lead needed to avoid a run-off and giving him another five-year term

Former Bolivian president Carlos Mesa (pictured) served as the country's leader from 2003-2005

Bolivian law enforcement agents detain a man during Monday's mass protests over results from the October 20 presidential elections

Morales is set to hold an event in El Alto, north of La Paz, later on Monday.

'The speed with which this is all happening is striking,' said politics professor Marcelo Arequipa, of San Pablo Catholic University.

While on Friday protesters called for a second round, now some are asking for the vote to be annulled, Arequipa said.

''(Morales) must go' may come next.'

A dummy of the Bolivian president was wrapped to a street pole Monday on a day anti-government demonstrators gather in large groups to protest election results
description: Protesters took to the streets of La Paz on Monday morning as in a mass demonstration over the October 20 elections that gave President Morales a fourth term in office.
